glossary/axiom-of-choice-(ac).html.title: Axiom of Choice (AC)
glossary/axiom-of-choice-(ac).html.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
Let be a set of non-empty sets, the axiom of choice (AC) asserts that there exists a choice functionfunction such that for every set , Informally, assigns to each set in a member of that set. Each choice function corresponds to one element in the cartesian product of the elements of the collection . Therefore, another way to state the AC is Given any family/collection of non-empty sets , their cartesian product is a nonempty set Another way PropertiesEquivalent to: Zorn's LemmaZorn's Lemma

glossary/cardinality.html.title: Cardinality
glossary/cardinality.html.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
Each set is assigned a certain object, called the cardinal number (or cardinality) of (), in such a way that two sets are assigned the same cardinality iff they are equinumerousequinumerous All infinite sets are big, however some are bigger than other. Cardinal numbers generalize “set size” to infinite sets.For finite sets, the standard definition of cardinality is the number of members of the set.Properties

glossary/chain.html.title: Chain
glossary/chain.html.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
Let be a set with an ordering relationordering relation . A subset is a chain iff for any two elements , either or A chain is a totally ordered subset of a posetposetThe chain has an upper bound iff for every element , EXAMPLE If is a set of sets and the ordering relation is : A collection of sets is a chain iff for any elements (sets) and in , either or
The upper bound of is PropertiesBy definition, a finite chain always has an upper bound. However, not every chain needs to have an upper bound.EXAMPLES Consider set $\N$ with ordering relation . Let chain . has no upper bound because for any element there is always a bigger number Another example is the set , the set of rational numbers less than . Which is a chain, does not have an upper bound

glossary/countable.html.title: Countable
glossary/countable.html.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
A set is countable iff there is some one-to-one functionfunction mapping set to the set of natural numbers ()
PropertiesL1. Let be a countably infinite set with one-one counting function . Then, we can extract a one-one onto counting function [1]T1. Let be a countable set, then the set of all finite sequences of members of is also countable[2]See Also
For some , is the least member of $ran$(), let
In general, there is some unique such that is the th least member of $ran$(), let ↩︎
For each finite sequence , assign number where is the th prime number and is the counting function of set ↩︎

glossary/cycle.html.title: Cycle
glossary/cycle.html.description:
abiteboul1995foundationsabiteboul1995foundations
A cycle is a path such that and A directed cycle is proper if is a proper pathAn undirected cycle is proper if is a proper path and [1]PropertiesIf has a cycle from , then has a proper cycle from See Also
Why ? In theory it can be a cycle, but it doesn’t look like a cycle because the same edge between two vertices qualifies for a cycle↩︎

glossary/equinumerosity.html.title: Equinumerosity
glossary/equinumerosity.html.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
Two sets and are equinumerous () iff there is a one-to-one onto functionfunction mapping onto EXAMPLE
$\N$ and $\Z$ are equinumerousPropertiesEquinumerosity is reflexive, symmetric and transitivetransitiveTwo finite sets have the same “size” iff they are equinumerous

glossary/function.html.title: Function
glossary/function.html.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
A function is a relation with the property of being single-valued i.e. for each in $dom$ , there is only one (denoted by ) such that We usually say ( maps to ) where
$dom$ and
$ran$ PropertiesSee Also

glossary/n-tuple.html.title: n-Tuple
glossary/n-tuple.html.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
An n-tuple is an extension of ordered pairs to include objects. It’s defined recursively
PropertiesL1. Every -tuple is an ordered pair
L2. If , then [1]

glossary/ordering-relation.html.title: Ordering Relation
glossary/ordering-relation.html.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
A binary relation defined on a set is an ordering relation if it allows for comparing elements of set . Ordering relations typically satisfy properties like TransitivityTransitivity and TrichotomyThere are two types of ordering relations: Partial OrderPartial Order and Total Order.When unspecified, an ordering relation usually refers to a total order.
Should ordering relations be reflexive? PropertiesSee Also

glossary/pairwise-disjoint.html.title: Pairwise Disjoint
glossary/pairwise-disjoint.html.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
A collection of sets (a set of sets) is pairwise disjoint iff any two members of the collection are disjoint i.e. their intersection is $\varnothing$PropertiesSee Also

glossary/partial-order.html.title: Partial Order
glossary/partial-order.html.description:
abiteboul1995foundationsabiteboul1995foundations
A partial order of is an ordering relationordering relation over that is
reflexive,
antisymmetric, and
transitivetransitive. The ordered pair is a partially ordered set (poset).A partial order allows for comparing some elements of PropertiesSee Also
Ordering RelationOrdering Relation
Total Order

glossary/transitive-relation.html.title: Transitive Relation
glossary/transitive-relation.html.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
A relation is transitive iff whenever both ordered pairs , then Properties

glossary/tree.html.title: Tree
glossary/tree.html.description:
abiteboul1995foundationsabiteboul1995foundations
A tree is a graph that has exactly one vertex with no in-edges (called the root) and no undirected cyclesundirected cyclesFor each vertex , there is a unique proper path from root to A leaf is a vertex of a tree with no out-edgesenderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
For each tree, there is a finite partial orderingpartial ordering . If , then is lower than and connected by a line.PropertiesA tree is connected but not strongly connected

glossary/zorn's-lemma.html.title: Zorn's Lemma
glossary/zorn's-lemma.html.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
Let be a set with an ordering relationordering relation such that for any chainchain , the upper boundupper bound of exists and is in . Then, there is some element which is maximal i.e. for any element , either or and are incomparable wrt EXAMPLE Let be a set of sets such that for any chainchain , the upper bound . Then, there is some element which is maximal i.e. it is not a subset of any other element of PropertiesEquivalent to: Axiom of Choice (AC)Axiom of Choice (AC)
#todo How is Zorn’s Lemma related to the Axiom of Choice?

literature-notes/enderton2001mathematica.title: A Mathematical Introduction to Logic
literature-notes/enderton2001mathematica.description:
(enderton2001mathematical, p.xi)
Symbolic logic is a mathematical model of deductive thought (enderton2001mathematical, p.xii)
The logical correctness of these deductions is due to their form but is independent of their content. enderton2001mathematical, p.xii Is there a gap between what we can prove in an axiomatic system (say for the natural numbers) and what is true about the natural numbers?
What is the connection between logic and computability? (enderton2001mathematical, p.xii) This book does not propose to teach the reader how to think. The word “logic” is sometimes used to refer to remedial thinking, but not by us. The reader already knows how to think.
Chapter 0 - Useful Facts about SetsChapter 0 - Useful Facts about Sets
Chapter 1 - Sentential LogicChapter 1 - Sentential Logic
Chapter 2 - First-Order LogicChapter 2 - First-Order Logic
Chapter 3 - UndecidabilityChapter 3 - Undecidability
Chapter 4 - Second-Order LogicChapter 4 - Second-Order Logic

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. Multiple values will be tried in order until one succeeds. Multiple values will not insert this feature multiple times.

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. Multiple values will be tried in order until one succeeds. Multiple values will not insert this feature multiple times.

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the closer connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make the graph appear more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. Multiple values will be tried in order until one succeeds. Multiple values will not insert this feature multiple times.

info_includePath.description: The path on the server from which this feature can be loaded

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded
